articles.headline: U.S. Strains to Stop Arms Flow
articles.snippet: Officials say they have been frustrated trying to block Syria, Iran and North Korea from selling to militants.
articles.abstract: Officials say they have been frustrated trying to block Syria, Iran and North Korea from selling to militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Just a week after President Bashar al-Assad of Syria assured a top State Department official that his government was not sending sophisticated weapons to Hezbollah, the Obama administration lodged a confidential protest accusing Syria of doing precisely what it had denied doing.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Service Members Face New Threat: Identity Theft
articles.snippet: The Social Security numbers of military personnel are used for everything from health forms to gym memberships.
articles.abstract: The Social Security numbers of military personnel are used for everything from health forms to gym memberships.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government warns Americans to closely guard their Social Security numbers. But it has done a poor job of protecting those same numbers for millions of people: the nation’s soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines.

articles.headline: Tax Deal Suggests New Path for Obama
articles.snippet: President Obama agreed to a tentative deal to extend the Bush tax cuts, part of a package to keep jobless aid and cut payroll taxes.
articles.abstract: President Obama agreed to a tentative deal to extend the Bush tax cuts, part of a package to keep jobless aid and cut payroll taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced a tentative deal with Congressional Republicans on Monday to extend the Bush-era tax cuts at all income levels for two years as part of a package that would also keep benefits flowing to the long-term unemployed, cut payroll taxes for all workers for a year and take other steps to bolster the economy.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Starbucks and Kraft Escalate Battle Over Marketing Pact
articles.snippet: Kraft asked a federal judge in Manhattan to stop Starbucks from breaking the 12-year partnership under which Kraft distributes Starbucks’ packaged coffees.
articles.abstract: Kraft asked a federal judge in Manhattan to stop Starbucks from breaking the 12-year partnership under which Kraft distributes Starbucks’ packaged coffees.
articles.lead_paragraph: A billion-dollar brouhaha between Starbucks and Kraft over supermarket coffee sales is turning into the venti latte of corporate divorces  with a double shot of espresso and extra foam.

articles.headline: Obama Urges China to Check North Koreans
articles.snippet: In a frank discussion, President Obama urged China’s president to put the North Korean government on a tighter leash after a series of provocations.
articles.abstract: In a frank discussion, President Obama urged China’s president to put the North Korean government on a tighter leash after a series of provocations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a sign of mounting tension between the United States and China over North Korea, President Obama telephoned President Hu Jintao and warned that China was emboldening its unruly neighbor by not publicly challenging its behavior, a senior administration official said Monday.

articles.headline: Iran’s Divorce Rate Stirs Fears of Society in Crisis
articles.snippet: The rate has tripled, but more surprising is women’s willingness to use the legal system to escape marriages.
articles.abstract: The rate has tripled, but more surprising is women’s willingness to use the legal system to escape marriages.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  The wedding nearly 1,400 years ago of Imam Ali, Shiite Islam’s most revered figure, and Fatemeh al-Zahra, the daughter of the Prophet Muhammad, is commemorated in Iran’s packed political calendar as a day to celebrate family values.

articles.headline: British Court Denies Bail to Assange
articles.snippet: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said he would resist extradition to Sweden, where he faces questioning in connection with alleged sex offenses.
articles.abstract: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said he would resist extradition to Sweden, where he faces questioning in connection with alleged sex offenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — After months of posting troves of classified American documents on the Internet, Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, surrendered to British authorities and was jailed on Tuesday after a judge reviewing a Swedish extradition request found him to be a flight risk and denied him bail.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Ravi Somaiya
